1970 – March 31, 1990 On loan to the Princeton University Art Museum (L.1970.196)
25th November 1991 Sold at Christie's - New York, Chinese Paintings & Calligraphy from the Ellen B. Elliott Collection, No. 29
1991 (?) – 2024 Collection of Nancy Lee, Hong Kong

Landscape became the preeminent painting genre in Chinese art during the Northern Song dynasty (960–1127), when the depiction of grand, towering mountains symbolized the solid structure of a well-ordered state. By the Yuan dynasty (1279–1368), members of the literati class transformed the landscape genre into a visual expression of the artist’s inner character, creating fantastical images of nature that could only be conjured in the mind. By the Ming (1368–1644) and Qing (1644–1912) dynasties, reverence and nostalgia for the idioms of Song-Yuan landscape painting had become prevalent in the works of many artists, including Gong Xian. This painting exhibits several hallmarks of Gong’s oeuvre—lush rocks formed with wet ink contrast with fine, dry brushwork delineating empty pavilions. This hanging scroll’s unusually tall and narrow format allowed Gong to create a landscape in four distinct horizontal tiers. The result is a brooding scene that plays with the visual idioms of the past even as the artist features his own unique style of brushwork.
